summary.brief_summary: This table describes IBM's commitment to creating an inclusive workplace through various diversity initiatives and employee support programs.
summary.detailed_summary: The table outlines IBM's approach to diversity and inclusion, highlighting their eight official diversity communities and workplace guidelines updated in 2022. It specifically details two key programs: the IBM Apprenticeship Program for skilled individuals without advanced degrees and the IBM Tech Re-Entry Program for professionals returning to the workforce after career breaks.
key_observations: IBM maintains eight official diversity communities including Women, LGBTQ+, DiversAbility, Black, Hispanic, Native American, Asian, and Veteran groups
IBM updated its Workplace Guidelines in 2022 to include inclusive facilities like all-gender restrooms and reflection rooms
The IBM Apprenticeship Program targets skilled individuals without advanced degrees
The IBM Tech Re-Entry Program offers paid 'returnships' for professionals rejoining the workforce after career breaks
summary.data_range: Current IBM diversity initiatives and programs as of 2022
summary.audience: Current and prospective IBM employees, investors, and stakeholders interested in IBM's ESG commitments

key_insights: IBM is taking a comprehensive approach to inclusion by addressing both physical workplace design and career development opportunities
The company recognizes the value of non-traditional talent through its Apprenticeship Program
IBM acknowledges career gaps with its Re-Entry Program, potentially addressing gender gaps in tech
Physical workspace modifications demonstrate IBM's commitment to accessibility and inclusion beyond just policies
trends: Focus on both physical and programmatic elements of inclusion
Emphasis on alternative pathways into tech careers
Recognition of diverse needs across multiple identity groups

chunks.content: Policy Advocacy Throughout the year, we also supported several bills brought forth to the U.S. Congress in support of our diverse communities of IBMers including: The Respect for Marriage Act, to protect marriage equality for LGBTQ+ and interracial couples, which Congress passed and was signed into law by the President in December 2022 The Equality Act, to extend civil rights protections to the LGBTQ+ community The Dream Act and the American Dream and Promise Act, to provide protections and certainty for Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) recipients, or DREAMers We advocate for our diverse IBMers globally and, in November, sent a letter to Slovakia’s Prime Minister urging the Slovak government to create a safe and welcoming environment for all following the murders of two members of Slovakia’s LGBTQ+ community. — — — Contents We recognize that for new-collar strategies to make an impact on the labor market at scale, we must work together. This is why we have partnered with t
chunks.page_title: IBM Policy Advocacy for Diverse Communities

chunks.content: s of Slovakia’s LGBTQ+ community. — — — Contents We recognize that for new-collar strategies to make an impact on the labor market at scale, we must work together. This is why we have partnered with the Consumer Technology Association to create the CTA Apprenticeship Coalition that helps companies launch apprenticeship programs in the U.S., are founding members of the OneTen Coalition and the New York Jobs CEO Council, as well as a chair of the Business Roundtable’s Multiple Pathways Initiative. These efforts work to improve opportunities by scaling new-collar programs and encouraging more companies to adopt skills-first talent strategies. Allyship IBM provides voluntary training and support to help every IBMer be an upstander through inclusive behaviors. In addition, we require all our employees globally to complete training on the Business Conduct Guidelines which includes learnings on sexual harassment, discrimination, bullying and retaliation prevention as part of its Introduction
chunks.page_title: IBM Policy Advocacy for Diverse Communities

chunks.content: ployees globally to complete training on the Business Conduct Guidelines which includes learnings on sexual harassment, discrimination, bullying and retaliation prevention as part of its Introduction Governance annual certification process. We regularly refresh education for our employees to help foster an inclusive culture and provide them with the tools and knowledge to become an Ally through our Be Equal® Ally Badge which has been earned by thousands of IBMers. The Be Equal Ally Badge is earned by IBMers who embody intentional and positive everyday efforts to advance and benefit people different from themselves. This badge is earned through demonstrated learning, volunteer effort, and advocacy and is assessed and approved by earners’ managers. Be Equal Ally Badge earners actively advocate through actions and activities to create a supportive, inclusive culture at IBM for all diverse communities. Social Environment Accountability IBM harnesses data transparency to enable accountabili
chunks.page_title: IBM Policy Advocacy for Diverse Communities

chunks.content: te through actions and activities to create a supportive, inclusive culture at IBM for all diverse communities. Social Environment Accountability IBM harnesses data transparency to enable accountability, action and outcomes for increased diversity representation and inclusion at every level of our company. Pay Equity Paying people fairly based on their job and without discrimination—regardless of gender or race—is not optional. It is a mandate that aligns with our values. IBM has a longstanding practice of pay equity and is firmly committed to equal pay for equal work. It has been part of our global policy since 1935—preceding the U.S. law by several decades. We have been conducting statistical pay equity analysis in the U.S. since the 1970s. To support our commitment to pay equity, each year we follow a consistent methodology to identify and address any pay equity gaps across genders globally and across races and ethnicities in the U.S. In 2022, all countries where IBM has employees w
chunks.page_title: IBM Policy Advocacy for Diverse Communities

chunks.content: ear we follow a consistent methodology to identify and address any pay equity gaps across genders globally and across races and ethnicities in the U.S. In 2022, all countries where IBM has employees were included in our pay equity analysis. We are proud of the results: overall, IBM pays equitably for similar work. Women globally earn $1.00 for every $1.00 earned by men for similar work. The same is true for underrepresented minorities in the U.S. Diversity-Linked Executive Compensation To reinforce our focus on improving the diverse representation of our workforce, we link executive compensation with the company’s performance in key diversity areas. A modifier for diversity results is included in the annual incentive program for our executives globally and is based on improvement in executive representation for women globally and U.S. underrepresented minority (URM) groups (specifically, Black and Hispanic) for our executives Appendix in the U.S. Our goal remains to improve and close t
chunks.page_title: IBM Policy Advocacy for Diverse Communities

chunks.content: ive representation for women globally and U.S. underrepresented minority (URM) groups (specifically, Black and Hispanic) for our executives Appendix in the U.S. Our goal remains to improve and close the gap in representation. Opportunities for Self-Identification Diversity and Inclusion have always been the cornerstone of our success as a company. IBM believes that providing opportunities for self- disclosure allows employees to voluntarily share their uniqueness. By self-identifying, we show awareness and may leverage differences by creating solutions and network opportunities for a successful company. Of employees who self-identified in 2022: — Over 9% self-identified as LGBTQ+ — Almost 5% self-identified as Veterans — Over 1% self-identified as People with Diverse Abilities Results inclusive of Red Hat. The privacy of our employees is our chief concern and IBM complies with all applicable legal requirements when handling this information. The indicator is designed so that only a spe
chunks.page_title: IBM Policy Advocacy for Diverse Communities

chunks.content: usive of Red Hat. The privacy of our employees is our chief concern and IBM complies with all applicable legal requirements when handling this information. The indicator is designed so that only a specific and limited number of professionals within the Diversity and Talent organizations have access to this information. Self-identification information is not visible to managers or team members and is held in strictest confidence. In 2022, of our global promotions, 42.2% were women and, of our U.S. promotions, 8.3% were Black employees and 7.7% were Hispanic employees. Results inclusive of Red Hat IBM 2022 ESG Report 28
chunks.page_title: IBM Policy Advocacy for Diverse Communities

It emphasizes IBM's commitment to pay equity, representation improvement, and creating an inclusive workplace culture where employees can self-identify and share their uniqueness.

The company partners with multiple external organizations to scale new-collar strategies
IBM uses data transparency for accountability in diversity representation
The company has specific policies around pay equity and self-identification opportunities
Diversity and inclusion are described as 'cornerstone of success' for IBM

extracted_table.title: Representation and Hiring Trends
extracted_table.notes: IBM hired over 59,000 employees in 2022. Women (data includes active regular employees). All data (except for women, as noted above) includes active regular and nonregular (supplemental) employees. Results inclusive of Red Hat, including prior years which have been restated.

summary.brief_summary: This chart illustrates IBM's representation and hiring trends across various demographic groups from 2020 to 2022, segmented by overall representation, management representation, and new hires.
summary.detailed_summary: The chart presents the percentage of women, Black, Hispanic, Native American, Pan-Asian, and Multi-race employees within IBM, both overall and in management positions. It also shows the percentage of new hires within these demographic groups. The data spans from 2020 to 2022, allowing for an analysis of trends in representation and hiring practices. The chart is divided into three sections: overall representation, management representation, and new hires.
key_observations: Representation of women has increased across all categories (overall, management, new hires) from 2020 to 2022.
Black representation in management has increased from 2020 to 2022, while new hires have decreased.
Pan-Asian representation has increased across all categories from 2020 to 2022.
Hispanic representation has increased in overall and new hires, but remained relatively stable in management.
Native American representation remains low across all categories.
summary.data_range: 2020-2022, across various demographic groups (Women, Black, Hispanic, Native American, Pan-Asian, Multi-race) within IBM, categorized by overall representation, management representation, and new hires.
summary.audience: IBM stakeholders, investors, employees, and anyone interested in IBM's diversity and inclusion efforts.
summary.purpose: To demonstrate IBM's progress and commitment to diversity and inclusion in its workforce.

trends: Increasing representation of women.
Increasing representation of Pan-Asian employees.
Relatively stable or slightly increasing representation of Hispanic employees.
Decreasing representation of Black employees in new hires.
Low and relatively stable representation of Native American employees.
patterns: A general trend of increasing representation across most groups, with some exceptions.
outliers: The decrease in Black representation in new hires in 2022.
correlations: Positive correlation between overall representation and new hires for women and Pan-Asian employees.
growth_rates: Positive growth rates for women and Pan-Asian representation.
Negative growth rate for Black representation in new hires.
trends.statistical_significance: Without statistical analysis, it's difficult to assess the statistical significance of the observed trends. Further analysis would be needed to determine if the changes are statistically significant or due to random variation.

key_insights: IBM is making progress in increasing the representation of women in its workforce.
The representation of Pan-Asian employees is increasing across all categories.
Black representation in new hires has decreased, which may warrant further investigation.
Native American representation remains a challenge.
Management representation generally lags behind overall representation, suggesting a need for focused efforts.
insights.business_implications: These findings suggest that IBM's diversity and inclusion initiatives are having some positive effects, but there is still room for improvement, particularly in management representation and specific demographic groups. The company may need to adjust its strategies to address areas where progress is slower.
recommendations: Continue and expand successful initiatives that are increasing representation, particularly for women and Pan-Asian employees.
Investigate the reasons for the decrease in Black representation in new hires and implement corrective actions.
Develop targeted programs to increase Native American representation.
Focus on promoting diversity within management positions.
Regularly monitor and report on diversity metrics to track progress and identify areas for improvement.
insights.limitations: The data is limited to the years 2020-2022 and may not reflect long-term trends. The data is also specific to IBM and may not be generalizable to other companies. The chart does not provide context on the specific initiatives that may have influenced the trends.
insights.comparative_analysis: Women's representation is consistently higher than other groups in overall and new hires. Pan-Asian representation shows consistent growth. Black representation in new hires has decreased, while Hispanic representation has increased. Native American representation is consistently the lowest across all categories.

chunks.description: The image contains multiple column charts displaying representation and hiring trends across different demographic groups (Women, Black, Hispanic, Native American, Pan-Asian, and Multi-race) for the years 2020, 2021, and 2022. The charts are divided into 'Overall' (including all members of the specific community) and 'Management' (including all executives and people managers) sections, as well as 'Representation' and 'New Hires' sections. The charts show percentages for each demographic group over the three-year period.

summary.brief_summary: This chart illustrates IBM's representation and hiring trends across various demographic groups from 2020 to 2022, segmented by overall employee base and management levels.
summary.detailed_summary: The chart presents data on the representation and new hires of women, Black, Hispanic, Native American, Pan-Asian, and Multi-race employees within IBM. It is divided into 'Overall' and 'Management' categories, showing percentages for both representation within the company and new hires. The data spans the years 2020, 2021, and 2022, allowing for trend analysis of IBM's diversity and inclusion efforts.
key_observations: Representation of women increased in both overall and management roles from 2020 to 2022.
Black representation in the U.S. increased in overall representation but decreased in new hires from 2021 to 2022.
Pan-Asian representation and new hires consistently increased across all categories.
Hispanic representation and new hires saw slight increases.
Native American representation and new hires remained low.
summary.data_range: 2020-2022, covering representation and new hires across various demographic groups within IBM, segmented by overall employee base and management.
summary.audience: Investors, stakeholders, employees, and anyone interested in IBM's diversity and inclusion performance.
summary.purpose: To demonstrate IBM's progress and commitment to diversity and inclusion initiatives, and to provide transparency on workforce demographics.

trends: Increasing representation of women.
Increasing representation of Pan-Asian employees.
Fluctuating trends for Black representation.
Low and relatively stable representation of Native American employees.
patterns: Consistent growth in Pan-Asian representation and new hires.
outliers: The relatively low representation of Native American employees compared to other groups.
correlations: Positive correlation between overall representation and new hires for most groups.
The representation of women is consistently higher than other groups.
growth_rates: Positive growth rates for women and Pan-Asian representation.
Fluctuating growth rates for Black representation.
trends.statistical_significance: Without further statistical analysis, it is difficult to determine the statistical significance of the observed trends. However, the consistent growth in women and Pan-Asian representation suggests a potentially significant trend.

key_insights: IBM is making progress in increasing the representation of women in its workforce.
The company is experiencing a mixed trend in Black representation, with increases in overall representation but a decrease in new hires.
Pan-Asian representation and hiring are consistently increasing.
The representation of Native American employees remains low.
The data suggests a focus on improving diversity and inclusion across the company.
insights.business_implications: These findings suggest that IBM's diversity and inclusion programs are having some positive effects, particularly for women and Pan-Asian employees. However, the company may need to re-evaluate its strategies for Black and Native American representation to ensure equitable hiring and promotion practices.
recommendations: Continue and expand successful diversity and inclusion programs.
Investigate the reasons behind the decrease in Black new hires and address any potential biases.
Develop targeted initiatives to increase Native American representation.
Monitor and report on diversity metrics regularly to track progress.
Consider setting specific goals for representation and new hires.
insights.limitations: The data is limited to the years 2020-2022 and may not reflect long-term trends. The data is also specific to IBM and may not be generalizable to other companies. The data does not provide information on intersectionality (e.g., women of color).
insights.comparative_analysis: Women's representation is consistently higher than other groups. Pan-Asian representation shows the most consistent growth. Black representation shows a mixed trend. Native American representation is consistently the lowest. New hire percentages generally reflect representation percentages, but there are some notable differences.

The data shows both current representation percentages and new hire percentages, allowing for comparison between existing workforce composition and recent hiring trends.
key_observations: Women represented 33.5% of IBM's global workforce in 2020, increasing to 37.3% by 2022
Black representation in the U.S. workforce increased from 6.6% in 2020 to 7.7% in 2022
New hires show higher diversity percentages than overall representation, with women comprising 39.5% of new hires in 2022
Management diversity shows lower percentages than overall workforce diversity for most demographic groups

key_insights: IBM is making gradual progress in increasing representation of women and underrepresented minorities in its workforce
New hire percentages for diverse groups are generally higher than current representation, suggesting a focus on diversity in recruitment
Management diversity lags behind overall workforce diversity, particularly for Black employees (5.7% in management vs. 7.7% overall in 2022)
The company appears to be tracking diversity metrics consistently over time as part of its ESG commitments
trends: Increasing representation of women globally from 33.5% in 2020 to 37.3% in 2022
Growth in Black representation in the U.S. from 6.6% in 2020 to 7.7% in 2022
Hispanic representation increased from 6.2% to 7.0% over the three-year period

Black new hires in management decreased from 9.8% in 2021 to 6.7% in 2022

It further breaks down these demographics for new hires. The data spans from 2020 to 2022, providing a snapshot of IBM's diversity and inclusion efforts over this period.
key_observations: Representation of women is increasing across both technical and executive levels.
Representation of Black employees is increasing in both technical and executive roles.
New hire data generally reflects the representation trends, with some fluctuations.
Pan-Asian representation shows consistent growth across both representation and new hires.
The representation of Native American employees remains low across all categories.
summary.data_range: 2020-2022, Technical and Executive levels, Global and U.S. demographics (Women, Black, Hispanic, Native American, Pan-Asian, Multi-race)
summary.audience: Investors, stakeholders, employees, and anyone interested in IBM's diversity and inclusion performance.
summary.purpose: To demonstrate IBM's progress in diversity and inclusion initiatives and to provide transparency on workforce demographics.

trends: Increasing representation of women across both technical and executive levels.
Increasing representation of Black employees across both technical and executive levels.
Generally stable or increasing representation of Hispanic employees.
Consistent growth in Pan-Asian representation.
Relatively low and stable representation of Native American employees.
patterns: A consistent pattern of increasing representation for women and Black employees.
A pattern of new hire data generally reflecting representation trends, but with some fluctuations.
outliers: The relatively low representation of Native American employees compared to other groups.
correlations: Positive correlation between representation and new hire data for most demographic groups.
Potential correlation between diversity initiatives and the observed trends.
growth_rates: Positive growth rates for women and Black employees in both representation and new hires.
Moderate growth rates for Hispanic and Pan-Asian employees.
trends.statistical_significance: Without further statistical analysis, it is difficult to assess the statistical significance of the observed trends. However, the consistent increases over multiple years suggest that the trends are likely to be meaningful.

key_insights: IBM is making progress in increasing the representation of women and Black employees.
The data suggests a commitment to improving diversity in new hires.
The representation of some groups, like Native American employees, remains a challenge.
Executive level representation lags slightly behind technical levels in some categories.
The data provides a clear picture of IBM's diversity journey over the observed period.
insights.business_implications: These findings suggest that IBM's diversity and inclusion programs are having a positive impact, which can enhance its reputation, attract talent, and potentially improve financial performance. Continued focus on underrepresented groups is crucial.
recommendations: Continue and expand successful diversity and inclusion programs.
Focus on strategies to improve representation of Native American employees.
Analyze the reasons for any discrepancies between representation and new hire data.
Set specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound (SMART) goals for diversity and inclusion.
Regularly monitor and report on progress.
limitations: The data is limited to the years 2020-2022.
The data may not reflect the full scope of IBM's global workforce.
The chart does not provide context on the specific initiatives driving the observed trends.
The data is presented as percentages, not absolute numbers, which limits the ability to assess the scale of change.
insights.comparative_analysis: The chart allows for direct comparison of representation across different demographic groups, job levels, and years. It also enables comparison between representation and new hire data, highlighting areas where hiring practices may be lagging or leading representation trends.

key_observations: Representation of women in both technical and executive roles has increased from 2020 to 2022.
The percentage of Black employees in technical roles has increased, while the percentage of Black new hires has fluctuated.
Pan-Asian representation and new hires have increased in both technical and executive roles.
Hispanic representation and new hires have increased in both technical and executive roles.

summary.purpose: To demonstrate IBM's progress and commitment to diversity and inclusion in its workforce.

trends: Increasing representation of women in both technical and executive roles.
Fluctuating but generally increasing representation of Black employees.
Consistent growth in Pan-Asian representation and new hires.
Slow but steady growth in Hispanic representation and new hires.
Low and relatively stable representation of Native American employees.
patterns: A general upward trend in representation for most demographic groups.

outliers: The relatively low representation of Native American employees compared to other groups.
correlations: Positive correlation between representation and new hires for most groups, suggesting that hiring practices are contributing to overall representation.
growth_rates: Positive growth rates for women, Black, Hispanic, and Pan-Asian representation and new hires, though the rates vary.
trends.statistical_significance: Without statistical analysis, it's difficult to determine the statistical significance of the observed trends. However, the consistent upward trends suggest that the changes are likely meaningful.

key_insights: IBM is making progress in increasing the representation of women in both technical and executive roles.
The company is also seeing improvements in the representation of Black and Hispanic employees.
New hire data suggests a continued focus on diversifying the workforce.
The representation of Native American employees remains low, indicating an area for potential improvement.
Pan-Asian representation and new hires are showing consistent growth.
insights.business_implications: These findings suggest that IBM's diversity and inclusion initiatives are having a positive impact. Continued efforts are needed to sustain and accelerate these trends, particularly for underrepresented groups. This can improve employee morale, attract talent, and enhance the company's reputation.
recommendations: Continue and expand successful diversity and inclusion programs.
Set specific goals for increasing representation in underrepresented groups, such as Native American employees.
Monitor hiring trends to ensure that new hires reflect the company's diversity goals.
Invest in programs that support the career advancement of diverse employees.
Regularly report on progress to stakeholders.
insights.limitations: The data is limited to IBM's workforce and may not be representative of the broader technology industry. The data does not provide information on intersectionality (e.g., women of color).
insights.comparative_analysis: The chart allows for a direct comparison of representation and new hires across different demographic groups and over time. For example, the increase in women's representation can be compared to the changes in Black or Hispanic representation. The comparison of representation versus new hires provides insights into the effectiveness of hiring practices.

It segments data by gender (women globally) and ethnicity (Black, Hispanic, Native American, Pan-Asian, and Multi-race in the U.S.) over a three-year period from 2020 to 2022, showing IBM's progress in diversifying its workforce at different organizational levels.
key_observations: Women's representation in technical roles increased from 27.4% to 29.6% globally from 2020 to 2022
Black representation in U.S. technical roles increased from 5.7% to 7.1% over the three-year period
Women's representation in executive positions increased from 27.7% to 30.3% globally
Pan-Asian representation in executive roles in the U.S. increased from 15.7% to 16.8% from 2020 to 2022
New hire percentages for women in technical roles reached 32.5% in 2022
summary.data_range: 2020-2022 for representation metrics across technical and executive positions, broken down by gender and ethnicity
summary.audience: IBM stakeholders, investors, ESG analysts, diversity and inclusion professionals, and regulatory bodies monitoring corporate diversity initiatives

key_insights: IBM has shown consistent improvement in women's representation at both technical and executive levels over the three-year period
Black and Hispanic representation in technical roles has shown steady growth, with Black representation increasing by 1.4 percentage points from 2020 to 2022
Executive diversity has improved more slowly than technical diversity, particularly for underrepresented minorities
New hire percentages for women and minorities are generally higher than current representation, suggesting continued diversification
The company specifically notes improvements in executive representation excluding Red Hat, indicating potential differences in diversity metrics between IBM proper and its acquisitions
trends: Consistent upward trend in women's representation across both technical and executive positions
Gradual increase in representation of Black and Hispanic employees in technical roles
Pan-Asian representation remains relatively stable but high compared to other minority groups
New hire percentages generally exceed current representation percentages, indicating a focus on diversifying through recruitment
anomalies: Native American representation remains very low (below 0.5%) with minimal change over the reporting period
Multi-race representation data appears incomplete or inconsistently reported across years
Some new hire data points appear to be missing or inconsistently formatted in the table
comparisons: Technical roles show higher representation of Black employees (7.1% in 2022) compared to executive roles (6.6% in 2022)
Women's representation is slightly higher in executive roles (30.3%) than in technical roles (29.6%) in 2022
Pan-Asian representation is significantly higher in technical roles (24.6%) than in executive positions (16.8%)

chunks.content: 32 IBM 2022 ESG Report Community Development Corporate social responsibility has been a hallmark of IBM’s culture for over 100 years. Together, we have a shared commitment to creating a better, more equi—for each other and within our global communities. During the past year we have launched, expanded, and enhanced innovative social impact programs that are driving greater global impact. IBM Giving and Volunteering Volunteerism and giving are at the epicenter of our work and are foundational to our commitment to advancing diversity, equity, and inclusion. IBM Giving Worldwide IBM has a comprehensive giving strategy that allows us to provide the breadth of our expertise, technology, and cash to support our Corporate Social Responsibility mission and priorities in education and skills, sustainability, and others. Our giving strategy is global and focuses on areas where IBM seeks to make a significant impact on those with the greatest need. In response to the devastating series

summary.brief_summary: This chart presents IBM's worldwide giving contributions, broken down by type and region, over a three-year period (2020-2022).
summary.detailed_summary: The chart provides a financial overview of IBM's corporate giving, including total contributions and their allocation across different categories like technology, services, and cash. It also details the distribution of these contributions across various geographic regions, allowing for a comparison of giving patterns over time. The data spans from 2020 to 2022, offering insights into how IBM's philanthropic efforts have evolved.
key_observations: Total contributions worldwide peaked in 2021 and decreased in 2022.
Technology contributions consistently represent the largest portion of giving by type.
Services contributions increased significantly from 2020 to 2022.
Asia Pacific saw a substantial increase in contributions in 2021, followed by a decrease in 2022.
North America and Europe, Middle East, Africa are the regions with the highest contributions.
summary.data_range: 2020-2022, IBM Giving Worldwide, by type (Technology, Services, Cash) and region (Europe, Middle East, Africa; Asia Pacific; North America; Latin America).
summary.audience: Investors, stakeholders, corporate social responsibility professionals, and anyone interested in IBM's philanthropic activities.
summary.purpose: To provide a transparent overview of IBM's financial contributions to various causes and regions, demonstrating its commitment to corporate social responsibility.

trends: Overall, total contributions decreased from 2021 to 2022.
Services contributions show an increasing trend.
Asia Pacific contributions increased significantly in 2021 but decreased in 2022.
North America contributions show a fluctuating trend.
patterns: The data suggests a pattern of fluctuating contributions across regions and types, potentially reflecting changes in global priorities or economic conditions.
outliers: The significant increase in Asia Pacific contributions in 2021 could be considered an outlier.
correlations: There appears to be a correlation between the overall economic climate and the total contributions worldwide.
growth_rates: Services contributions show a positive growth rate over the three-year period.
trends.statistical_significance: Without further statistical analysis, it's difficult to determine the statistical significance of the observed trends. Further analysis would be needed to determine if the observed changes are statistically significant.

key_insights: IBM's total giving fluctuates year-over-year, with 2021 being the highest.
Technology consistently receives the largest share of IBM's contributions.
Services contributions are growing, indicating a shift in giving strategy.
Regional distribution highlights IBM's focus on North America and Europe, Middle East, Africa.
The data suggests IBM adapts its giving based on global events and priorities.
insights.business_implications: The data can inform decisions about resource allocation, geographic focus, and the types of programs supported. It also reflects IBM's commitment to its corporate social responsibility goals, which can impact its brand reputation and investor relations.
recommendations: Analyze the reasons behind the fluctuations in total contributions and regional allocations.
Investigate the drivers behind the growth in services contributions.
Evaluate the effectiveness of giving programs in each region.
Consider aligning giving strategies with broader business objectives and societal needs.
insights.limitations: The chart only presents financial data and does not provide information on the impact or outcomes of the giving programs. It also does not include qualitative data about the specific initiatives supported.
insights.comparative_analysis: Technology contributions are significantly higher than services and cash contributions. North America and Europe, Middle East, Africa consistently receive the largest share of contributions compared to Asia Pacific and Latin America. The year 2021 shows the highest total contributions, driven by increases across multiple categories.

summary.brief_summary: This table presents IBM's global giving contributions from 2020 to 2022, broken down by type (technology, services, cash) and geographic regions.
summary.detailed_summary: The table details IBM's philanthropic contributions worldwide from 2020 to 2022, showing a peak in 2021 at $474.1 million before decreasing to $447.9 million in 2022. Contributions are categorized by type (with technology being the largest component) and by geographic region. The table is part of IBM's broader ESG reporting on social initiatives, including skills development and sustainability commitments.
key_observations: Total worldwide contributions peaked in 2021 at $474.1 million before declining to $447.9 million in 2022
Technology contributions consistently represent the largest portion of IBM's giving (over 75% each year)
Service contributions increased significantly from $42.1 million in 2021 to $64.7 million in 2022
Cash contributions remained relatively stable across all three years (around $44 million)
Europe, Middle East, and Africa received the largest regional allocation of contributions
summary.data_range: 2020-2022 fiscal years
summary.audience: Investors, ESG analysts, corporate social responsibility professionals, and stakeholders interested in IBM's social impact

key_insights: IBM's giving strategy heavily emphasizes technology contributions over cash donations, leveraging their core business assets for social impact
There was a notable 53.7% increase in service contributions from 2021 to 2022, suggesting a strategic shift toward more hands-on engagement
Despite a 5.5% decrease in total contributions from 2021 to 2022, the overall giving in 2022 remained 12.5% higher than in 2020
IBM's giving aligns with their strategic initiatives in education (30 million skilled by 2030) and sustainability ($30 million commitment)
trends: Technology contributions follow the same pattern as total giving: increasing in 2021 and then decreasing in 2022
Service contributions show a consistent upward trend over the three-year period, growing from $36.8M to $64.7M
Cash contributions remain remarkably stable across all three years, suggesting a fixed budget allocation
anomalies: The significant increase in service contributions in 2022 (53.7% growth) stands out compared to the overall decrease in total giving
2021 appears to be an exceptional year with peak giving across most categories
comparisons: Technology contributions ($338.4M in 2022) dwarf both service ($64.7M) and cash contributions ($44.8M)
Europe, Middle East, and Africa received the highest regional allocation ($151.1M in 2022) among the regions shown

chunks.content: 33 IBM 2022 ESG Report IBM Volunteers® IBM Volunteers leverages the collective power of people and resources to ensure meaningful impact worldwide. The program supports active and retired IBMers who donate their time and talents to academia, grassroots initiatives, and organizations helping to build our communities—and their efforts qualify for IBM grants to the eligible organizations they support. IBM Volunteers has more than 100,000 registered users where we logged over 437,000 volunteer hours in 2022.* IBM Service Corps gives IBMers the opportunity to use their professional skills to help communities tackle complex challenges in education, humanitarian efforts, cybersecurity, and economic development. Since 2008, IBM Service Corps has engaged more than 8,400 employees to undertake 470 projects in 56 countries. Volunteering Hours 2021 2022 Worldwide retiree and employee volunteer hours 440K1 437K2 1Restatement from prior year to reflect calculation correction 2Results inclusive of Red Hat *Results inclusive of Red Hat Education & Skills We believe the talent gap is one of the biggest challenges facing businesses today. Through our social impact programs, IBM is meeting the needs of multiple learners. We have committed to skill 30 million people by 2030 with a focus on individuals that have been historically underrepresented in the technology field. Since 2021, over 7 million learners* have enrolled in free IBM courses through our combined education initiatives and, in 2022, we contributed over $435 million in combined cash, technology, and services toward education. Our cornerstone education programs are: IBM SkillsBuild® IBM SkillsBuild is a free education program that provides valuable skills and career opportunities to traditionally underrepresented communities in
chunks.page_title: IBM Volunteers: Community Impact and Service Corps

main_topics: Technology Skills Training for Underrepresented Communities

chunks.content: ornerstone education programs are: IBM SkillsBuild® IBM SkillsBuild is a free education program that provides valuable skills and career opportunities to traditionally underrepresented communities in technology. The program, which offers over 1,000* courses in 20* different languages on cybersecurity, data analysis, cloud computing and many other technical disciplines in addition to workplace skills, includes learners around the world who are predominately high school and university students, faculty, or adult learners. The program includes an online platform that is complemented by customized practical learning experiences delivered in collaboration with a global network of partners. HBCU Cybersecurity Leadership Centers IBM is collaborating with over 20 HBCUs to create IBM Cybersecurity Leadership Centers that will advance STEM-based opportunities for students. Through this collaboration, faculty and students at participating schools will have access to coursework, lectures, immersiv
chunks.page_title: IBM Volunteers: Community Impact and Service Corps

main_topics: Technology Skills Training for Underrepresented Communities

chunks.content: Leadership Centers that will advance STEM-based opportunities for students. Through this collaboration, faculty and students at participating schools will have access to coursework, lectures, immersive training experiences, certifications, IBM Cloud®-hosted software, and professional development resources, all at no cost to them. STEM for Girls STEM for Girls , which launched in India in 2019, is designed to foster a robust STEM ecosystem that encourages critical thinking, problem solving and innovation among the upcoming generation of women in India. Through mentorship and project- based learning pathways, middle school and high school young women are exposed to different careers in STEM. P-TECH® In 2011, IBM co-created P-TECH as an innovative high school model incorporating post-secondary pathways and workplace experiences aligned to career readiness. Today, it has evolved into a successful, global, open-source model that includes mentoring, career exploration and access to IBM SkillsBuild. summary.brief_summary: This chart presents the volunteering hours contributed by IBM's worldwide retirees and employees in 2021 and 2022.
summary.detailed_summary: The table displays the total volunteer hours for IBM's global workforce, including retirees and current employees. It provides a comparative view of volunteer hours between 2021 and 2022, allowing for an assessment of the company's community engagement efforts. The data highlights the scale of IBM's volunteer programs and their impact. The chart includes footnotes indicating a restatement from the prior year and results inclusive of Red Hat.
key_observations: IBM volunteers contributed a significant number of hours in both 2021 and 2022.
The total volunteer hours decreased slightly from 2021 to 2022.
The data includes both retiree and employee volunteer hours.
The chart provides a clear comparison of volunteer hours across two years.
Footnotes clarify data adjustments and scope.
summary.data_range: The data covers the years 2021 and 2022, focusing on worldwide retiree and employee volunteer hours.
summary.audience: Stakeholders interested in IBM's corporate social responsibility, including investors, employees, and the general public.
summary.purpose: To showcase IBM's commitment to community engagement and the impact of its volunteer programs.

trends: A slight downward trend in volunteer hours from 2021 to 2022.
trends.patterns: The data shows a consistent pattern of significant volunteer hours, indicating an ongoing commitment to community involvement.
trends.outliers: There are no apparent outliers in this simple two-year comparison.
trends.correlations: There are no variables to correlate in this chart.
trends.growth_rates: The growth rate is negative, indicating a decrease in volunteer hours.
trends.statistical_significance: With only two data points, statistical significance cannot be assessed.

key_insights: IBM's volunteer programs are substantial, with hundreds of thousands of hours contributed annually.
There was a slight decrease in volunteer hours from 2021 to 2022.
The data reflects the combined efforts of both current employees and retirees.
The chart provides a clear metric for measuring the impact of IBM's community involvement.
The inclusion of footnotes indicates data refinement and scope.
insights.business_implications: The data suggests a strong commitment to community engagement, which can enhance IBM's reputation, attract and retain talent, and potentially improve stakeholder relations. The slight decrease in hours may warrant further investigation to understand the underlying causes.
insights.recommendations: Monitor volunteer hours annually to track trends and identify areas for improvement. Investigate the reasons behind the decrease in volunteer hours from 2021 to 2022. Consider expanding volunteer programs or initiatives to further increase community impact.
insights.limitations: The chart only presents the total volunteer hours and does not provide details on the types of activities, geographic distribution, or specific impact of the volunteer efforts. The footnotes indicate data adjustments, which should be considered when interpreting the data.
insights.comparative_analysis: The chart allows for a direct comparison of volunteer hours between 2021 and 2022, revealing a slight decrease. This comparison highlights the need to understand the factors influencing volunteer participation.

chunks.content: Call for Code Call for Code, the largest tech for good initiative of its kind, calls on teams of developers and problem solvers to build technology solutions that leverage IBM AI technologies to address specific global sustainability problems in clear and unique ways. In 2022, GardenMate, a marketplace app that connects those with a surplus of fresh produce to local consumers, won our 2022 Call for Code Global Challenge which saw participation from thousands of developers, students, enterprise developers, and partners. Contents Introduction Governance Social Environment Appendix Sustainability We believe the power of science, technology and innovation can help tackle environmental issues while serving the communities exposed to environmental hazards. By uniting experts and technology with the purpose of improving the lives of populations most affected by environmental threats, we have the potential to make a lasting, scalable impact on populations in need. IBM Sustainability Accelerato
chunks.page_title: IBM Call for Code: Technology for Global Sustainability

chunks.content: the purpose of improving the lives of populations most affected by environmental threats, we have the potential to make a lasting, scalable impact on populations in need. IBM Sustainability Accelerator In 2022, we announced the IBM Sustainability Accelerator, a pro bono social impact program that applies IBM technologies, such as hybrid cloud and AI, and expertise to enhance and scale nonprofit and government organization solutions, helping populations especially vulnerable to environmental threats. Our first cohort, which began work in 2021, is focused on sustainable agriculture, while our cohort announced at COP27 in November 2022 focuses on clean energy. We plan to select five organizations for this program each year and have committed $30 million worth of cash, services and technology by the end of 2025. In 2022, we contributed over $4.7 million to promote environmental sustainability related to these programs. 34 IBM 2022 ESG Report
chunks.page_title: IBM Call for Code: Technology for Global Sustainability

chunks.content: 35 IBM 2022 ESG Report Supply Chain Social Responsibility In 2022, we spent $17.5 billion with over 10,000 suppliers of hardware, software, and services, and continued to promote social and environmental responsibility among our global supply network and across our industry. On a comparative basis with 2021, both purchasing spend and number of suppliers are considerably reduced as a result of the separation of our managed infrastructure business in November 2021. Since 2010, IBM has required its first-tier suppliers to create and maintain a social and environmental management system to address their responsibilities within a year of starting to do business with us. IBM suppliers must establish their management systems, measure performance, set goals, disclose results, and cascade these requirements to their upstream suppliers who perform work material to the goods and services provided to IBM. See the IBM Supply Chain Responsibility website for more details. Information on our promotio
chunks.page_title: IBM Supply Chain Social Responsibility

chunks.content: uirements to their upstream suppliers who perform work material to the goods and services provided to IBM. See the IBM Supply Chain Responsibility website for more details. Information on our promotion of environmental responsibility among our global supply chain can be found in the Supply Chain Environmental Responsibility section on page 49. Responsible Business Alliance (RBA): IBM is a founding member of the RBA, a nonprofit industry group that enables its members to strive for continuous improvement in the social, environmental, and ethical responsibility of their companies, and upstream supply chains. We require our first-tier suppliers of hardware, software, and services (as well as IBM’s internal operations) to adhere to the RBA Code of Conduct, which contains provisions on labor, health and safety, environmental requirements, ethics, and management systems. The RBA code is the foundation for the social and environmental management system criteria that we require our suppliers t
chunks.page_title: IBM Supply Chain Social Responsibility

chunks.content: ealth and safety, environmental requirements, ethics, and management systems. The RBA code is the foundation for the social and environmental management system criteria that we require our suppliers to maintain. To help suppliers meet our requirements, we provide and facilitate education, including online access to the RBA learning academy that we augment with IBM developed materials. We regularly update these programs to address areas where assessments have revealed needed improvement. We encourage our suppliers to publish ESG reports to help drive greater supply chain transparency and best practice sharing. Our top 50 Production and Logistics suppliers and top 50 Services and General Procurement suppliers for 2022 are listed on page 53. From this group, 74 published ESG reports with 61 following GRI guidelines (as does IBM). The data spans three years, allowing for a comparison of spending trends. The total spending is also provided for each year, offering a consolidated view of IBM's supplier expenditures. key_observations: Total supplier spending decreased from 2020 to 2022.
Services and General procurement represents the largest spending category.
North America consistently accounts for the highest regional spending.
Spending in Europe, Middle East, and Africa decreased significantly from 2020 to 2022.
All regions and categories show a decrease in spending from 2020 to 2022.

Decreasing spending across all categories and regions.

The dominance of Services and General procurement suggests a shift towards service-based offerings.
The significant spending in North America indicates a strong presence and reliance on suppliers in this region.
The decline in spending across all categories and regions could reflect cost-cutting measures, changes in business strategy, or external economic factors.
The data provides a baseline for assessing the impact of IBM's supply chain initiatives.

The regional distribution highlights areas of strategic importance and potential risks. The category breakdown informs resource allocation and supplier relationship management.
recommendations: Investigate the reasons behind the spending decline to understand its drivers and implications.
Analyze the performance of suppliers in different regions to optimize the supply chain.
Monitor the impact of spending changes on supplier relationships and business outcomes.
Assess the potential risks associated with the concentration of spending in specific regions.

insights.comparative_analysis: Spending in Services and General procurement is significantly higher than in Production and Logistics procurement. North America's spending is much higher than other regions. All categories and regions show a decrease in spending from 2020 to 2022.

summary.brief_summary: This table presents IBM's supplier spending by category from 2020 to 2022, showing a decline in overall procurement expenditure from $24.2 billion to $17.5 billion.
summary.detailed_summary: The table details IBM's procurement spending across three categories (Services and General, Production, and Logistics) over a three-year period from 2020 to 2022. It shows a significant reduction in overall spending from $24.2 billion in 2020 to $17.5 billion in 2022, with the largest decrease occurring in Services and General procurement. The data is presented in the context of IBM's supply chain social responsibility initiatives.
key_observations: Total procurement spending decreased by 27.7% from 2020 to 2022
Services and General procurement saw the largest decline, dropping from $20.3B in 2020 to $14.0B in 2022
Production procurement remained relatively stable, decreasing slightly from $3.3B to $3.1B
Logistics procurement had minimal change, decreasing from $0.6B to $0.5B
In 2022, IBM worked with over 10,000 suppliers across hardware, software, and services

summary.audience: Investors, ESG analysts, supply chain professionals, and stakeholders interested in IBM's procurement practices and social responsibility

key_insights: IBM has significantly reduced its procurement spending by approximately $6.7 billion (30%) over a three-year period, potentially indicating strategic cost-cutting measures or operational efficiency improvements
Despite the reduction in spending, IBM maintains its commitment to social and environmental responsibility in its supply chain
The company requires first-tier suppliers to adhere to the RBA Code of Conduct, demonstrating a focus on ethical standards
The most substantial spending reductions occurred in Services and General procurement, suggesting potential shifts in IBM's business model or outsourcing strategy
Production procurement remained relatively stable, indicating continued investment in core product development

Services and General procurement shows the steepest decline (31% reduction from 2020 to 2022)
Production and Logistics procurement categories show more stability with smaller percentage decreases
anomalies: The significant reduction in supplier count and spending in 2022 compared to previous years is noted as unusual and attributed to specific business changes
comparisons: Services and General procurement consistently represents the largest spending category (80-84% of total spending across all years)
Production procurement represents about 14-18% of total spending across the three years
Logistics procurement consistently represents the smallest category at approximately 2-3% of total spending

chunks.content: 36 IBM 2022 ESG Report Supplier Audits Annually, a cross-section of our first-tier suppliers are requested to participate in RBA-Validated Audits to gauge their conformance to the RBA code and to IBM’s requirements. If an RBA full audit reveals nonconformance, we work with suppliers to review their corrective action plans and suggest recommendations to reach code conformance. IBM steadfastly follows the RBA assessment process and requires reaudits for these suppliers to measure their progress toward full conformance. In 2022, IBM suppliers participated in 60 RBA full- scope audits and 46 reaudits in 19 countries where heightened risks for social and environmental responsibility are known to exist. 2022 Full Audits and Reaudits by Country Full Audit Reaudit Total China 21 13 34 Mexico 5 5 10 India 2 8 10 Thailand 3 6 9 Philippines 4 3 7 Singapore 4 3 7 Taiwan 3 3 6 Brazil 4 1 5 Korea 3 1 4 Romania 3 0 3 Malaysia 2 0 2 Hungary 1 1 2 Japan 0 1 1 United States 1 0 1 Bulgaria 1 0 1 Columbia

Labor-related issues account for the largest portion (42%), followed by Health and Safety (32%), Management Systems (17%), Environmental (6%), and Ethics (3%). This breakdown provides insights into the areas where IBM's suppliers need the most improvement to ensure compliance.
key_observations: Labor nonconformances represent the largest category, indicating a significant area of concern.
Health and Safety is the second most prevalent area of nonconformances.
Management Systems also contribute a substantial portion of nonconformances.
Ethics and Environmental issues have a relatively smaller impact compared to Labor, Health and Safety, and Management Systems.
The chart is based on 60 full audits, providing a snapshot of supplier performance.

summary.purpose: The purpose of this chart is to provide a visual representation of the areas where IBM's suppliers are experiencing nonconformances, allowing for targeted improvement efforts and demonstrating IBM's commitment to responsible sourcing.

trends: The data suggests a persistent trend of nonconformances in labor practices and health and safety.
The chart provides a snapshot in time, so no trends can be determined without historical data.

outliers: Labor nonconformances are a significant outlier compared to other categories.
correlations: There may be a correlation between the size or complexity of a supplier and the likelihood of nonconformances, but this cannot be determined from the chart.

trends.statistical_significance: Without additional data, it is not possible to assess the statistical significance of the observed patterns.

key_insights: Labor practices are the most significant area of nonconformances, indicating a need for focused improvement efforts.
Health and Safety is a major area of concern, suggesting potential risks to worker well-being.
Management Systems require attention to ensure effective implementation of RBA standards.
The data highlights the importance of ongoing audits and corrective action plans.
The chart provides a clear overview of the areas where IBM's suppliers need to improve.
insights.business_implications: The findings suggest that IBM needs to prioritize efforts to address labor practices, health and safety, and management systems within its supply chain. This may involve increased training, stricter enforcement of standards, and closer monitoring of supplier performance. Addressing these issues can mitigate risks, improve brand reputation, and ensure ethical sourcing.
recommendations: Implement targeted training programs for suppliers on labor practices, health and safety, and management systems.
Increase the frequency or intensity of audits in areas with high nonconformance rates.
Strengthen corrective action plans and follow-up procedures to ensure that suppliers address identified issues.
Consider incentivizing suppliers to improve their performance in these areas.
Collaborate with suppliers to share best practices and provide support.
insights.limitations: The chart is based on a limited number of audits (60 full audits), which may not fully represent the performance of all IBM suppliers. The data only reflects nonconformances identified during audits and may not capture all instances of noncompliance. The chart does not provide information on the severity of the nonconformances.
insights.comparative_analysis: Labor nonconformances are significantly higher than any other category, highlighting a disproportionate level of concern. Health and Safety is the second highest, indicating a need for more attention than Management Systems, Ethics, and Environmental issues.

chunks.content: 37 IBM 2022 ESG Report The 60 full audits revealed a total of 324 nonconformances against the five provisional sections of the RBA Code—the 10 most frequent nonconformances are shown in the  the immediate right. Versus 2021, IBM observed a net reduction in the number of code nonconformance reported from these RBA full audits. This was the result of the positive impact of our supplier engagement (training and consultation on the shortfalls within their RBA Self-Assessment Questionnaires), and a higher ratio of hardware suppliers audited (most with prior RBA audit experience). In 2022, IBM collaborated with 46 suppliers to plan and execute RBA reaudits to vet corrective action plans associated with full audits performed during 2021-2022. These reaudits yielded a 71% improvement in conformance from the findings in the related full audits. In this same group, 48% of suppliers attained full conformance to the RBA Code after one cycle of audit, correction action, and reaudit. We rema
chunks.page_title: IBM 2022 ESG Report: Supplier Audit Findings

chunks.content: nformance from the findings in the related full audits. In this same group, 48% of suppliers attained full conformance to the RBA Code after one cycle of audit, correction action, and reaudit. We remain engaged with suppliers that show residual nonconformance and require a second corrective action plan to be developed for further assessment. As part of our RBA Code conformance management system, we review full and reaudit results monthly with IBM’s procurement teams and vice presidents, and quarterly with our Chief Procurement Officer. From this dialogue, we make alterations to our supplier education programs, assistance, and future sourcing patterns. 15.7% 20.1% 9.3% 13.3% 5.2% 8.0% 4.6% 7.1% 4.0% 5.9% 3.1% 5.9% 2.8% 3.7% 2.2% 3.1% 2.2% 2.5% 1.5% 2.2% 2022, 60 Full Audit Results (Top 10 nonconformances to RBA code provisions by %) Priority & Major Nonconformance Minor Nonconformance Working Hours Emergency Preparedness Freely Chosen Employment Wages and Beneﬁts Occupational Safety Occ

chunks.content: 38 IBM 2022 ESG Report Modern Slavery and Forced Labor Over the past decade, there has been growing realization of the circumstances surrounding the involuntary exploitation of individuals under modern slavery and the potential for forced labor in extended supply chains. Through our membership in the RBA, we have been active in addressing this issue. In 2020, RBA membership adopted a code change that explicitly addressed parameters to prevent forced labor in the supply chain. We have built upon the RBA code provisions to develop online training for our buyers and employees and have collaborated with external parties to create a technology platform to assist multi-stakeholders in interrupting modern slavery. Annually, we publish two reports in response to Australian and United Kingdom legislation with details on our activities to combat modern slavery and forced labor. These reports are updated each June and are available on our IBM Impact website. Responsible Minerals Sourcing Since th
chunks.page_title: Modern Slavery and Forced Labor

organizations.text: Organisation for Economic Co-Operation and Development

legal_references.text: Section 1502 of the Dodd-Frank Financial Reform Act of 2010

chunks.content: lation with details on our activities to combat modern slavery and forced labor. These reports are updated each June and are available on our IBM Impact website. Responsible Minerals Sourcing Since the passage of Section 1502 of the Dodd- Frank Financial Reform Act of 2010, our focus has been to ensure that 3TG minerals (tantalum, tin, tungsten, and gold) used in our products do not contribute directly or indirectly to armed groups in the Democratic Republic of the Congo and adjoining countries. We deploy a multifaceted approach that includes robust policies and practices, as well as external collaboration, to reach these objectives. Our responsible minerals sourcing policy is aligned with the framework of the Organisation for Economic Co-Operation and Development (OECD) Due Diligence Guidance for Responsible Supply Chains of Minerals from Conflict-Affected and High-Risk Areas (CAHRAs), including Annex II and the related supplements pertaining to downstream companies. IBM has expanded
chunks.page_title: Modern Slavery and Forced Labor

organizations.text: Organisation for Economic Co-Operation and Development

legal_references.text: Section 1502 of the Dodd-Frank Financial Reform Act of 2010

chunks.content: ance for Responsible Supply Chains of Minerals from Conflict-Affected and High-Risk Areas (CAHRAs), including Annex II and the related supplements pertaining to downstream companies. IBM has expanded its efforts to include ethically sourced cobalt, following the approach we built with our suppliers on 3TG. We are an active member of the Responsible Minerals Initiative and engage directly with our in- scope suppliers to collaborate and build capacity, to assure lasting progress. We require in-scope suppliers to source 3TG minerals from ethical smelters or refiners (SORs) that are conformant or active in a recognized third-party validation scheme, or from 100% recycled scrap sources. IBM pairs skilled members of our responsible minerals team with first-tier (and upstream) suppliers to work on training, best practice sharing, and overcoming the challenges of a dynamic market environment where SOR status changes occur and must be adapted to. Our working relationships span multiple layers o
chunks.page_title: Modern Slavery and Forced Labor

organizations.text: Organisation for Economic Co-Operation and Development

legal_references.text: Section 1502 of the Dodd-Frank Financial Reform Act of 2010

chunks.content: n training, best practice sharing, and overcoming the challenges of a dynamic market environment where SOR status changes occur and must be adapted to. Our working relationships span multiple layers of the supply chain, in which many interrelationships exist, in order to sustain progress. As a complementary activity, IBM’s Responsible Minerals team maintains communications with our research community to keep them abreast of the challenges in the marketplace associated with minerals sourcing. This can help to influence future development of products. As an example, the IBM Almaden Research Center has invented a battery technology free of nickel and cobalt, which could potentially help eliminate the need for critical metals in battery production and transform the long-term sustainability of many elements of our energy infrastructure. chunks.content: IBM’s Global Supplier Diversity Program, in existence for over 50 years, operates in all countries where we do business, and diverse suppliers provide products and services for each of our procurement categories. We require our first-tier suppliers to report their own diverse supplier expenditures that are utilized in support of IBM contracts. Contents Supplier Diversity We recognize that a diverse supplier base is integral to our company’s profitability and strategic objectives — solidifying the connection between customer satisfaction and success in the marketplace. Our supplier diversity program* includes suppliers that are majority owned, operated, and controlled by people from a racial or ethnic minority (as defined in each applicable country or region), women, military veterans, LGBTQ+ individuals, or people with diverse abilities. Learn more about our program at the IBM Global Procurement website. Introduction Governance Social Environment Appendix Building and maintaining a com
chunks.page_title: IBM Global Supplier Diversity Program Overview

chunks.content: Q+ individuals, or people with diverse abilities. Learn more about our program at the IBM Global Procurement website. Introduction Governance Social Environment Appendix Building and maintaining a community of diverse suppliers increases IBM’s opportunity to hear new ideas, apply different approaches, and gain access to additional solutions that respond to customer needs. Such collaboration helps IBM deliver innovation, quality products, and world-class service to a growing global marketplace. IBM has committed to dedicating 15% of our first-tier supplier diversity spending to Black-owned businesses by 2025. In 2022, 6.9% of our first-tier supplier diversity spend was with Black-owned suppliers. This data highlights IBM's efforts to support diverse suppliers and its global reach in procurement.

It also suggests a focus on ESG factors, which are increasingly important to investors and customers.

chunks.content: 1988: First waste recycling goal 1990: Began annual corporate environmental reporting 1991: Integrated design for environment practices into product development 1994: Began annual corporate reporting of CO2 emissions 2001: First purchase of renewable electricity 2007: Published formal position on climate change 2015: Publicly supported the Paris Agreement — — — — — — — Contents Introduction Governance Social Environment Appendix Global Environmental Management System IBM views environmental leadership as a long-term strategic imperative. For more than 50 years, we have committed to environmental responsibility in all our business activities—a commitment formalized by our first corporate environmental policy in 1971, which integrated environmental responsibility throughout the fabric of our business. IBM’s corporate environmental policy provides the strategic framework for the company’s global environmental management system (EMS). We have maintained an EMS for decades and continually u
chunks.page_title: IBM Environmental Sustainability Timeline

organizations.text: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

chunks.content: business. IBM’s corporate environmental policy provides the strategic framework for the company’s global environmental management system (EMS). We have maintained an EMS for decades and continually update it to reflect our company’s intersections with environmental matters. Setting and executing against voluntary goals to drive continual improvement is an integral part of our EMS. The global scope of our EMS covers hardware product design and development, manufacturing, data centers, real estate operations, procurement, logistics, asset recovery services, and business services. Since 1997, we have continuously maintained our single global registration to the ISO 14001 EMS standard. We also have maintained a single global registration of our EMS to the ISO 50001 energy management systems standard since 2012. In addition, our GHG emissions quantification process is certified against the ISO 14064-1:2018 standard and our GHG emissions inventory and disclosures are verified with limited a
chunks.page_title: IBM Environmental Sustainability Timeline

organizations.text: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

chunks.content: tandard since 2012. In addition, our GHG emissions quantification process is certified against the ISO 14064-1:2018 standard and our GHG emissions inventory and disclosures are verified with limited assurance by an independent third-party using the ISO 14064­ 3:2019 standard. Stakeholder Engagement We proactively engage and collaborate with stakeholders from a cross-section of nongovernmental organizations (NGOs), government agencies, businesses, industry associations, investors, academia, communities, and employees on environmental matters. Some examples include: The Climate Registry (TCR) – As a longtime proponent of transparency in environmental reporting, we supported the development of the recently launched Net-Zero Portal by TCR. Since 2020, we have participated in TCR’s working group defining the principles, objectives, framework, and questionnaire in support of this initiative. The Net-Zero Portal is a public, online platform that collects information on “net zero” GHG pledges
chunks.page_title: IBM Environmental Sustainability Timeline

organizations.text: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

chunks.content: p defining the principles, objectives, framework, and questionnaire in support of this initiative. The Net-Zero Portal is a public, online platform that collects information on “net zero” GHG pledges made by organizations and how entities plan to meet their commitments and their progress. National Science Foundation (NSF) Convergence Accelerator – IBM Research has partnered with OntoChem, the University of Pittsburgh, Cornell University, and NuMat Technologies with additional guidance from the Semiconductor Industry Association (SIA) PFAS Consortium and the Division of the National Toxicology Program – National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (DNTP/NIEHS) to help accelerate the discovery of alternatives to per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), which are concerning because of their persistence in the environment and their potential for toxicity. This project, centering on the development of a PFAS Toolkit for Innovating Replacements (PFASTIR), is one of 16 multidiscipli
chunks.page_title: IBM Environmental Sustainability Timeline

organizations.text: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

chunks.content: of their persistence in the environment and their potential for toxicity. This project, centering on the development of a PFAS Toolkit for Innovating Replacements (PFASTIR), is one of 16 multidisciplinary teams selected to participate as part of the NSF’s Convergence Accelerator program’s 2022 cohort for Track I: Sustainable Materials for Global Challenges. Southwest Urban Corridor Integrated Field Laboratory – Led by Arizona State University and funded by a five-year grant by the U.S. Department of Energy’s Office of Science, IBM Research, in partnership with the other two major public universities in Arizona, two national laboratories and other local stakeholders, will help advance urban climate solutions by researching the effects of extreme heat, atmospheric pollutants, and limited water supply, especially for Arizona’s vulnerable communities. UN Science-Policy-Business Forum on the Environment (UN-SPBF) – As a founding member, we continue to work with the UN-SPBF to demonstrate ho
chunks.page_title: IBM Environmental Sustainability Timeline

organizations.text: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

chunks.content: er supply, especially for Arizona’s vulnerable communities. UN Science-Policy-Business Forum on the Environment (UN-SPBF) – As a founding member, we continue to work with the UN-SPBF to demonstrate how data and advanced information technology can underpin new solutions to persistent environmental problems. In 2022, representatives from IBM Research and IBM Software presented on technology and transformation at the 4th Global Session of the UN-SPBF. Refreshed in 2021, our 21 environmental sustainability goals establish transparent targets that address: — Energy and climate change — Conservation and biodiversity — Pollution prevention and waste management — Supply chain and value chain — Environmental management system IBM 2022 ESG Report 41

chunks.content: Energy and Climate Change 42 IBM 2022 ESG Report Our energy and GHG emissions goals and reporting cover facilities owned or leased by IBM, inclusive of Red Hat. These facilities include IBM data centers located in facilities managed by third parties where we do not procure the energy or control the operations of the buildings—also known as co-location data centers. Our goals for energy efficiency and conservation, renewable electricity procurement and GHG emissions reduction include: Procure 75% of the electricity IBM consumes worldwide from renewable sources by 2025, and 90% by 2030. Reduce IBM’s operational GHG emissions 65% by 2025 against base year 2010, adjusted for acquisitions and divestitures. Reach net-zero operational GHG emissions by 2030, using feasible technologies to remove emissions in an amount which equals or exceeds IBM’s residual emissions. Correspondingly, aim for residual emissions of 350,000 metric tons (MT) of CO2 equivalent or less by 2030. • With reference to t

Implement a minimum of 3,000 new energy conservation projects to avoid the consumption of 275,000 megawatt-hours (MWh) of energy from 2021 to 2025. Energy Conservation During 2022, we implemented 519 energy conservation projects across more than 150 locations globally, avoiding 71,000 MWh of energy consumption and 25,600 MT of CO2 emissions, saving $9.5 million.1 Our efforts included strategic adjustments to lighting levels, temperature, and other building systems to avoid unnecessary energy consumption as we adapted to new levels of onsite working. Most of our data centers now incorporate hot/cold aisle containment.2 In addition, we continued to execute projects aimed at enhancing the energy efficiency of both cooling and IT equipment, retrofitting lighting systems, and optimizing the operational efficiency of our building infrastructure. 1In measuring performance against IBM’s energy conservation goal, we only include the first year’s savings from projects. Accordingly, IBM’s total energy savings an

Accordingly, IBM’s total energy savings and CO2 emissions avoidance from these projects are greater than this simple summation of the annual results. We do not include reductions in energy consumption resulting from downsizings, the sale of operations or cost-avoidance actions, such as fuel switching and off-peak load shifting, in our energy conservation results. 2Hot/cold aisle containment is a strategy used in data centers to improve energy efficiency and reduce cooling costs. It involves organizing server racks in a way that achieves the greatest separation of hot exhaust air and cold intake air. In 2021, we set a goal of 3,000 energy conservation projects by 2025.
